Schools are fully open.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705171450/https://covid19.uis.unesco.org/global-monitoring-school-closures-covid19/country-dashboard/

Workplace policies are left to individual company's digression, with many big companies choosing to continue work from home or hybrid strategies.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705172434/https://hrmasia.com/big-companies-in-india-continue-hybrid-work-policies/

Public events can go ahead in a "pre-covid manner", except with masks and social distancing measures in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173743/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/covid-restrictions-to-end-from-tomorrow-here-s-what-will-change-on-april-1-11648709496612.html

There are no restrictions on gatherings.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173743/https://www.livemint.com/news/india/covid-restrictions-to-end-from-tomorrow-here-s-what-will-change-on-april-1-11648709496612.html

Public transport is open, though hours of operation vary throughout India depending on regional COVID-19 measures. Face-masks are almost universally required on public transport across India.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Some states and localities have quarantine measures in place.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Some states require either proof of COVID-19 vaccination or a current negative test result and/or testing on arrival if entering from other Indian states. Additional quarantine may be required dependent on state of origin.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Vaccinated travellers are able to enter India without having to test or self-isolate but are advised to self-monitor for 14 days. Unvaccinated travellers must provide proof of a negative PCR test result from the past 72 hours. All arriving passengers will be subject to thermal screening, and if symptomatic may be isolated.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173029/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/india/entry-requirements
No support found.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705174607/https://www.mygov.in/covid-19/

There is a national scheme in place for debt relief.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705175238/https://zeenews.india.com/personal-finance/big-relief-for-borrowers-on-loan-moratorium-cabinet-sanctions-rs-973-crore-2429276.html
Up to date information is available via the government website.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705174607/https://www.mygov.in/covid-19/

Tests are available throughout India in both private and government facilities. Testing at government hospitals throughout India is free to the public.  Costs for testing at a private facility or in a private residence are set by state governments and range from Rs 400 to Rs 2,250 per person for PCR tests. All those who have symptoms of the COVID-19 with the below criteria should test for Novel Coronavirus or COVID-19:  - International travel history in the last fourteen days  - Healthcare workers  - Those who have come in contact with confirmed cases  - Those who have been hospitalized with Influenza-Like Illness (ILI) or Severe Acute Respiratory Illness (SARS)  - Those living in the same household with confirmed case(s) should test once between 5 and 14 days  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ &

Contact tracing activites are being conducted in certain regions.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705175412/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/districts-look-to-ramp-up-testing-contact-tracing/articleshow/90921998.cms

Face masks are almost universally required to be worn in public, especially in urban areas, indoors, and on public transportation.  These regulations are being strictly enforced.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All aged 12 years and older are eligible for COVID-19 vaccines. Covishield (AstraZeneca), Covaxin, Corbevax, and Sputnik vaccines are in use.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705173902/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No specific policy found.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220705174607/https://www.mygov.in/covid-19/

13th Jun, COVID-19 preventative measures and restrictions are still in effect in some destinations.  These could include:  - curfews, movement restrictions, or lockdowns  - mandatory mask use  - required proof of vaccination or a COVID-19 test result to access public and private services and spaces  Before travelling, verify if specific restrictions or requirements are still in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220621193017/https://travel.gc.ca/destinations/sri-lanka

Nepal schools reopened on February 13th. In late April, the 10th-grade students completed their Secondary Education Examination (SEE) in Nepal.  Till the time they join higher education, there is a break of around three months.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220214234133/https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/south-asia/schools-reopen-in-nepal-as-third-wave-of-covid-weakens/articleshow/89540371.cms  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530221031/https://english.onlinekhabar.com/school-student-use-break-productively.html

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211735/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

Vaccinated visitors must present a certificate showing a negative RT-PCR test, taken within 72 hours of flight of first departure.  Unvaccinated people, or those unable to show that they have been fully vaccinated for at least fourteen days, are subject to free antigen tests on arrival. Although poorly enforced, mask compulsory everywhere outside. The government of Nepal has announced that failure to wear a mask outdoors may result in arrest and a fine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211735/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220606211639/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/entry-requirements

According to MoH Nepal, as of mid June 2022, 77.1% of the population have received the 1st dose and 68.6% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 7 Nepalese, 14% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/  21 more million doses to be delivered by June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/

According to MoH Nepal, as of mid June 2022, 77.5% of the population have received the 1st dose and 69% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 7 Nepalese, 14% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    US donates 2.2 million doses of Pediatric COVID-19 vaccines to Nepal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620223334/https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/us-donates-22-million-doses-of-pediatric-covid-19-vaccines-to-nepal

According to MoH Nepal, as of late June 2022, 78.3% of the population have received the 1st dose and 69.5% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 7 Nepalese, 14% of the population has received a booster, after six months of booster campaign.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523165444/https://covid19.who.int/region/searo/country/np/    According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has adminstered 9 vaccines (Moderna's Spikevax, Pfizer/BioNTech Comirnaty, Gamaleya's Sputnik V, Janssen's Ad26.COV2.S, Oxford/AstraZeneca's Vaxzevria, Serum's Covishield, Bharat Biotech's Covaxin, Sinopharm's Covilo and CoronaVac).  See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220523164846/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    Government began massively administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for children 5-12 on June 23th:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220627191919/https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/covid-19-vaccine-to-be-administered-to-children-in-the-5-12-age-group-from-today/    US donates 2.2 million doses of Pediatric COVID-19 vaccines to Nepal:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220620223334/https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/us-donates-22-million-doses-of-pediatric-covid-19-vaccines-to-nepal

According to MoH Nepal, as of early July 2022, 80.1% of the population have received the 1st dose and 69.9% are fully vaccinated.
